You have covered a great many points here and in each case you hit the nail on the head. I used to be in contracting and acquisitions with the Government for many years before I retired. The one main thing you point out was the fist thing that bothered me when I was working there, but I was unable to come up with an answer. What is your answer to letting a contract which was completely inovative meaning there were times the research and development that went into bidding for contracts a) would have to be eaten by the company that did NOT get the bid and b) would have to be changed along the way because of unforeseen consequences. That is the reason you can not put a money cap on this sort of project. And the contracting vehicle, as you say, has "baked into it" the flexibility one needs to succeed. Yes there are contracting officers (CO's) responsible to watch the funds after the contract has been let to make sure gigantic cost overruns are necessary to the fulfullment of the project and he has the power
to STOP a project dead in its tracks. He is often dependent on TR's ( Governemt technical representatives) who, depending how strongly they present their case, can guide the CO's to the right conclusion. But under the circumstances where, as you indicate, we were in a race with the Russiians, no CO would do that, no matter what the cost. It works pretty much the same way today. So how would you solve the problem where no one can foresee the appropriate path to follow when hitherto today untested and new technologies are implemented?

We gave up the Apollo program in order to focus on the upcoming Space Shuttle. Rockwell, who built the Shuttle, promised huge savings through reusability. What we got was a less efficient system, that could only reach leo. As our Shuttles got older, the maintenance became even more expensive than Apollo's disposable approach. The Shuttle did bring some unique abilities to NASA's tool box. It was the most expensive way ever devised to get a human into leo. After the accident with Space Shuttle Columbia, it seemed a good time to wind down the Shuttle program. We learned alot, including the fact that the Space Shuttle was a Lamborghini, not the efficient work truck we needed. NASA is no stranger to cost overruns, they are an aerospace research and development operation, not a business. Commercial space flight is based on the science that the Russian and American government run space programs have learned. Now that spaceflight has been solidified into an engineering challenge, it should be clearly a commercial application. NASA should, instead, be always focused on the mission, and the science. A good rocket, like a good truck, should be outsourced; when possible. Until Starship actually flies, the SLS program should continue. If we want to be spacefarers, we must remain committed. We lost our ability to put man on the moon, getting it back was never going to be anything but expensive. If we lose momentum again, we should just call it quits.

Why reinvent the wheel? Modernize/update Saturn/Apollo, and we'll get to the moon faster, better, safer, and for a lot less money. The Russians stayed with soyuz, and today they have one of the most reliable systems around. Had the US stayed with Saturn/Apollo, the US could have launched all the payloads launched by the shuttle, and gone to the moon 100 times (twice a year for 50 years), built a moon base, a space station (or two) and probably would not have lost 14 astronauts on the "failure is an acceptable option" space shuttle. As it stands now, the US is worse off than it was 60 years ago - the US has no launch vehicle, no working capsule, no space plane; and the existing program is on track to cost 4 or more times as much and take 3 to 4 times as long.

The fundamental problem with NASA is it is a third payer system.

People are spending money that is not theirs, on something someone else will use. There is no incentive to spend wisely and no incentive to create a product of value. I knew a contracting company owner who built many of the modern facilities NASA is currently using. While the contracts go to the lowest bidder, there is no restriction on change orders. The bureaucrats will sign any check sent to them, especially by companies who promise a kick back. Its not their money, and if they need more they have the endless access to taxpayers pockets.

The only way space travel will ever become viable is if the state gets out of the way of private companies who actually have a the proper incentive structure to undertake such a task.

The story of Constellation and Artemis seems taken from a manual of economics.
When an oligopoly consolidates (as US space industry was thirty years ago), oligopolists have the tendency to build a cartel and give to the customer less and less for more and more money. The regulator, thanks to good lobbyists, does not say anything or even changes the rule to give a further advantage to the oligopoly; innovation stops and cheap (for the oligopolists) solutions are preferred. Money is preferably used for lawyers, lobbyists and "gifts", rather than for investments.
Situation changes only if government finds the way to break the cartel or if external and powerful subjects enter into the game, determined to make a space for themselves in the oligopoly or to replace one (possibly all) oligopolists with themselves.
In my opinion, the facts that Artemis is finally moving on and that space industry is undergoing a dramatic change is no coincidence: because the industry is evolving so fast with powerful newcomers, then traditional fat cats have been somehow forced to move on and contracts also had to change (i.e. the number and relative force of lobbyists is changed, and we see the result). Should newcomers have not grown in number, capacity and size (with one new major player already emerged and another one growing, backed from almost unlimited funding) now we would probably see the re-enactment of the Constellation Program tale, with traditional large player spending money for lobbying and law cases rather than to develop new systems, giving less and less for more and more money, literally recycling over and over old stuff and eventually coming to nothing, in order to restart the game again with a new program name.
Also, the growth of Chinese space industry is a powerful stimulus: pressure on government agencies and politicians now does not come only from domestic lobbies. Something had to change.
Still in my opinion, considering constraints (uncertain funding, hard lobbying and political pressure to shower powerful companies with money while ensuring to pepper as many States as possible with some contracts), the best solution would have been for NASA to please the political/lobbying constituency with the dumbest possible update of the Apollo program (allowing even more profits for the companies, and maybe getting in exchange a shorter development time and a semi-obsolete, but altogether functioning launch system), considering it just a "sunk cost" to get something which would have at least avoided the ten-years humiliating gap in ISS cargo and crew support capacity, while going on with the commercial programs to get really innovative stuff from newcomers.
If the point was just to give out money to Pratt&Whitney, Boeing and Lockheed Martin etc, using a contract which provides a premium for delays and costs overrun, at least they could have chosen to recycle/revamp the best performing stuff, not the leftover from failed or disputable programs.
Once said this, yes, Artemis will be probably something really different from Apollo on steroids and will really represent the dawn of a new era in space industry, but the loads of money and time wasted before arriving there will be horrendous...

Apollo started for the same reason it ended: To satisfy the political needs of the president at the time. After making his famous speech about landing on the Moon within the decade (Which Congress approved thanks to the political influence of Lyndon B. Johnson), Kennedy realized that support for such a massive/expensive program wouldn't last. So he wanted to cancel Apollo even before it got off the launch pad. It was President Johnson who kept the program running and NASA saw it's largest budget during his presidency. President Nixon carried out the inertia of the program. But, After Apollo 11 landed on the Moon NASA had to flight to survive. Due to the Vietnam war (excuse me, CONLFICT) and the social atmosphere at that time, it wasn't popular to spend a lot of money in the space program. That's why After Apollo 11, Nixon slashed NASA's budget and the agency entered a slow decay that went all the way through the Space Shuttle program until today. Skylab was conceived using the scraps of Apollo. The last Apollo spacecraft was waisted on the political shenanigan called the "Apollo-Soyuz Test Project", which did NOTHIN to advance space flight nor to improve the Soviet-American relationship. The space shuttle was barely approved by a single vote. After the Challenger disaster President Reagan wanted to keep the shuttle flying due to its military potential for DOD missions. Finally, after the Columbia disaster Congress saw an opportunity to cancel the program and the only thing that kept it going was the building of the ISS. After the ISS was completed it was game over for NASA and I knew that the space shuttle was going to be NASA's last manned spacecraft for a long, LONG time. SLS doesn't have, not even near, the political drive Apollo had. Unfortunately, today not enough Americans are interested in space exploration for x, y or z reason and it painfully shows. Spending a lot of money on the space program is still hugely unpopular. Which is why today Americans are flying into space on vehicles made by everybody, but NASA. After the shuttle it was the Russians and now SpaceX (Well, at least SpaceX in within the US).

For those who say that SLSis somehow "stupid" and should be cancelled:
The REAL purpose for SLS is to get NASA a heavy lift rocket they've been wanting for ages, with the lowest amount of engineering required - as it was thought "for cheap". Although it turned out to be expensive, most of these costs have been recurrent ones - engineer salaries, factory maintenance, etc. If most of your yearly budget for a project are costs you have to pay every year, it baloons up. Just a simple example:
You need to produce something for 60 dollars and you need to spend 80$ per X time for food, rent, etc.
If your boss gives you 100$ per X, you will spend a total of 300$ before the project is complete, but if he gives you 140$ per X then you only spend the 140$. Although it may seem counter-intuitive, sometimes the cheapest way to get something done is to give the one doing it more money.

Please don't blame the fantastic AGC for "setting off alarms"! The 1201/1202 alarms were the computer warning its users that it was handling a problem, which in this case was caused by a hardware fault in the landing radar. The radar's data connection to the computer was configured incorrectly, causing it to send more data packets than it was supposed to. The computer was severely overworked and ran out of working memory multiple times because of having to handle this. However it recovered every time. "Computer alarm 1202" basically means "I have run out of memory but I am handling it automatically".

I understand your point that Artemis is supposed to be more than just Apollo repeated, but longer stays on the moon are meaningless if the goal is to do something revolutionary compared to what Apollo already did. It doesn't matter that each mission will spend 7 times as long on the surface if they only do it once a year. SLS is not at all sustainable because for Artemis to do something truly new and unique, we need more than 10 people per year to land on the surface. Unless they can reduce the price and increase the cadence by a couple orders of magnitude, SLS needs to be replaced ASAP by something that can launch enough people to establish a permanent human presence on the moon.

The way I see it, spending less than a month per year on the moon is just Apollo 2.0. But if Artemis can establish a 100% human presence, as the ISS has done with LEO, then that would actually set it apart from Apollo. With SLS, Artemis is just Apollo 2.0. Something else is absolutely required for Artemis to truly go further than her brother. This isn't "orange rocket bad," it's "orange rocket can't put 10 people on the surface every year for more than a few weeks per year while being absurdly expensive." SLS and Starship are at similar development points despite SLS having a significant head start, more funding, and borrowed technology. It may bring the first people to moon in this century, but it won't be able to establish a human presence on the moon that Apollo didn't do already. It may carry more people for longer, but that is a simple numerical upgrade, not a revolutionary change. And besides, the Saturn V with a faster launch cadence put more people on the moon per year during its peak than SLS will ever be able to with only one rocket per year.

My thoughts:   NASA is the major component of the discretionary portion of the federal budget.    That is, a government facing large debt, as we do, and large deficit, as we do,  will find in NASA the only way to reduce spending by tens of billions of dollars per year with no political penalty.   The greatest danger to NASA is in the first year of a new president, as now, and the first sign of monetary deflation, as now, along with the stirrings of rampant price inflation, as now.    Add to this political risk the observation that commercial interests seem to be moving along quite well to creating their own systems of interplanetary travel, and a U.S. government can make a compelling case to end or greatly reduce NASA.   For now, Feb 2021, it seems that this government is willing to keep NASA whole for this year.   The pressures building against NASA will become apparent after the pandemic ends.   A government needing to reconstitute a broken society, as we have become, will have no interest in supporting NASA, even as a symbolic example of American prestige.  It was, after all, cisgendered white male Americans (and a few NAZIs) who created the Mercury/Gemini/Apollo story.

Your count of Saturn V's built, tested, and flown is off. There was only 13: SA501, SA502, Apollo's 8 through 17, and Skylab 1. As far as built, there was also hardware for Apollo 18 and 19, but Apollo 20 was pretty much a myth and I believe the hardware for Apollo 18 became Skylab 1. Since the 70's , there have been full Saturn V's laying horizontal at Kennedy, Johnson, and Huntsville, but little effort was made to keep mission specific hardware grouped together and they are all a mish-mash of actual flight ready hardware, boiler plate stages, and stages from the Facilities Check vehicle, which was never a flight capable object.

I want interplanetary probes mass-produced, and launched at every launch window. I want space telescopes mass-produced, so that every university can have their own instead of queuing up for scarce time on Hubble and its successors. I want asteroids brought to cis-lunar space and used to make everything. I want a space elevator on the moon. I want aluminum/oxygen rockets flying around cis-lunar space, with all the expendable parts made from ordinary moon rock and solar energy. I want reusable reaction mass: I want to have a mass driver on one spacecraft launch material, and then have a mass-driver-in-reverse on another spacecraft catch it.

Catching a chunk of metal thrown at rocket-exhaust speeds would be insanely difficult. But it's not physically impossible, and reusable reaction mass would free us from the rocket equation and open up lots of possibilities.

As well as being one of the greatest footballers in history. Cristiano Ronaldo puts a lot of importance on his family. The Portuguese star is extremely close to his oldest brother, Hugo. He even saved his big brother's life!



In 2014, Hugo was going through a very difficult period. Teetering on the edge, his day to day life was impacted by the alcohol and drugs he was taking. His life was clearly in danger.



Not able to cope seeing his brother in such a state, CR7 decided to act. He made a deal with him, if he wins the Champions League, Hugo has to definitively give up alcohol and drugs. At the end of the match, CR7 ran up to his brother and hugged him, whispering to him: "Now it's your turn."



Hugo also kept his promise and no longer drinks alcohol or takes drugs. His brother even paid for his treatment. On that day, the younger brother became an inspiration for his older brother.

We should have inflatable domes, which we cover with 3D printers with simulated moon mortar. The domes should be connected to each other by inflatable tunnels covered with simulated moon mortar. There should be living quarters, hydroponic green houses, gardens with garden soil for recreational gardening, a 5 acre pasture with one inch of garden soil and one inch of grass turf, a park with artificial turf and with small sections of real grass turf, and maybe even a very small zoo. All the domes will have plastic floors so no water is lost. Condensation forming on the ceilings will be drained into the water supply. All the domes will be blown up with compressed air from earth and will have a refresh system, which will refresh the air and maintain the air pressure. Humidity, Temperature will be maintained by humidifiers, heaters, fans and coolers. Light will be provided by multi-color LEDs, mostly white. Power will be supplied at first by solar power, and later by nuclear or fusion power. All water will be re-cycled, almost zero loss of water. There will be a bull, a cow, two sheep, and two goats, two chickens, two turkeys, two fish, and two rabbits. There will also be pets, two dogs, two cats, two bunnies, etc. (and maybe a small zoo) All of this will be set up by astronauts and robots before the colonist arrive.

The first colonist will be 5 fathers and 5 mothers, and 90 babies. The parents will be good parents, gardeners, farmers, zoo keepers, teachers, etc.. During the first two years an exact duplicate facility will be built on the moon. When the babies are two years old, they will move to the moon and live on the moon. Or if it is proven that they will be too young to travel to the moon than the facility on earth will be added to, to accommodate 10 more parents and 90 more babies. The two year olds would move into the new addition. Every two years the facility will be either added to, or 100 people will move to the moon. This plan will allow the kids to grow up in the isolation of the colony, and will make it easier for them to live in the isolation of the colony on the moon. And will allow them to grow up on the moon and be better able to adjust to the lower gravity on the moon, although some artificial gravity maybe eventually provided. This artificial gravity will especially be good for the parents. The kids will have everything in the facility to keep them occupied and entertained. Also they could have some books, movies, games, etc., especially adapted for them, being careful not to give them anything that would make them feel isolated.

After 20 years there could be 2000 people living on the moon, most of whom grew up on the moon. This program could be speeded up so in 20 years there could be 4000, 6000, or 8000 people living on the moon.

This program could be simultaneously done to colonize Mars so we could have 2000 people on the Moon and Mars at the same time. For the moon we could send supplies every month, but for Mars we could only send supplies every 26 months. So I suggest we send 10, 20, or 30 rockets to Mars every 26 months all at the same time.

We could have several refueling stations along the way to mars and orbiting mars so rockets could refuel along the way to mars and right before landing on mars so the empty rocket would have enough fuel to take off again, refuel in space and return to Earth. Eventually the colonist could grow trees, bamboo, and other plants for raw materials that could be used for making things. Eventually the moon and Mars could export minerals or small expensive items that were assembled on the moon or Mars, like jewelry, iphones, iwatches, etc. Or grown on the moon like caviar, marijuana, etc.

Wouldn't it make more sense, to stage dozens of part into LEO. Either by themselves or to the ISS or another station, using multiple cheaper heavy-lift missions to build a station that could then go to the moon in one go. Using the ISS or another such facility as a staging area would reduce the need to take the heatshield with you on every mission. Astronauts can be housed on the staging station. Then they could be brought back using a simple low cost crew vehicle like SpaceX's Crew Dragon, or Boeings capsule. Which has already proven it can handle the re-entry phase.

This means you only need to have a transfer vehicle to the moon side gateway. and you could assembly and send cargo on these transfer missions. to build a larger and more useful gateway, that could eventually send a lot of its resources to a potential lunar base.
It would also get you a larger more capable vessel that doesn't try to do it all in one go. but builds its capability with every mission, and can handle a much longer-term mission and more science done on-site, rather than through a relay of materials from the surface.

All in one go, works for exploration, but not for colonization. It would be better to take more with you, do more there, and make less trips overall.

This would also make sense as it generates valuable info on staging, in space construction and deployment of larger space vehicles. Since that is required for the colonization of Mars in a meaningful way.

It could also lend to the construction of a lunar orbital elevator. which is wholly attainable with modern materials and upcoming launch vehicles. Why blow money on tiny missions that can't do a whole lot. Why not solve the larger issues. Build an elevator you now no longer need a lunar lander, and only need a transfer vehicle. Why waste loads and loads of time and money discarding stages and vehicles in one-offs. If you're going to put something into space or onto the moon. Why not make it part of a building block for something larger and far more useful?

The human transport version would carry a modified red dragon capsule that comes out of the starship cargo bay in LLO and lands on an artificial hard surface to avoid dust pickup.
The red dragon returns to the recently refueled starship in LLO and returns to LEO where it docks with a dragon 2 to take the crew back to earth.

Red dragon returns inside the lunar starship cargo where both get refueled (no humans on board during refueling). The lunar starship human transport will orbit the earth to await the next mission.

One day kids will look back on these figures and say "how did the project cost "x" times as much? Boeing is not telling the world 'warts and all' estimates......these are as palatable as they could make them whilst still passing internal checks and balances.
>On the question of how the the estimates come out so high, well, it isn't the physical work, the sheets of metal, the welding, etc, Elon figured that out, its largely all about the people, the company overhead applied and the profit margin demanded.....and you end up with unimpressive figures for those because the wages are generally reasonably high (£100k+), the legacy staff overhead (sorry to say it), people who may have been good in their time, but now no longer have the mental and physical fitness to contribute meaningfully at 50hr+ weeks.....and the profit margins are presumably still being maintained at inflated levels vs what they would have to be if the contracts were being competed for openly.
>SpaceX is delivering because it has minimal overheads, very minimal numbers of unproductive legacy staff, presumably a long hours culture.......etc, etc. all of which is great as long as you can take the pace. SpaceX must know that it cannot compete for these contracts currently due to political considerations, so its strategy will be to develop the technology in parallel to the point where it becomes inarguable that they should be allowed to provide some of the functionality i.e. heavy lift capability, at which point Boeing would be sidelined i.e. use up the legacy engines and call it a day, unable to develop its own next generation engines/rocket.
>Some of this also is about a country maintaining it skills and military capability. Sure they are making a moon rocket today, but if the world changed and suddenly you needed to go to war, all those Boeing engineers are suddenly available to you....and for them to be there when you need them, you need to maintain that capability today.

Artemis is much more flexible in the scheme. There is much higher safety standard, vast experience from ISS program, lot of options in every stage (thanks to amazing private companies to provide redundancies to the entire program). Last but not the least, Artemis is an international endeavor unlike Apollo. Apollo was just 'going, touching, returning' by USA alone. Artemis is more generic and broad: It's the next level of humanity's sustainable expansion into the new frontier. It's not based on a race of very political nature but the next logical scientific step forward after ISS program. ISS has proven that through international collaboration and commercial partnerships, costly space projects can be made sustainable- especially if there is a business/economic angle. Artemis is based on this very philosophy as far as I've understood. I wholeheartedly want to see its success and I am optimistic at that for the above-mentioned reasons.

Lets think about this on Elon-scale for a second!  I suspect SpaceX will have multiple ways to conduct refueling in orbit and beyond. The Pac-Man cargo Starships could easily contain fuel pods that can be quickly ejected into parking orbits or with their own engines they could be sent to the moon and beyond for sending fuel ahead of Starships so they can pick-up fuel at their destination, or on the way allowing for extended deep space missions to other moons. If Starships can refuel mid-flight they could increase their speeds allowing for quicker flights, and for changing their flight paths. This could be helpful in emergencies. I believe the Butt to Butt refueling will be too slow for many missions and SpaceX will want to offer orbital refueling as a service to other businesses and governments. Future craft may just want to strap on some fuel pods for their flights out of earth orbit to wherever they're going.  SpaceX could have several orbital fuel pod farms with hundreds or thousands of fuel pods in orbit and traveling back and forth to the Moon and other destinations where fuel can be made. It won't be long before fuel is being delivered from our Moon and other moons to bring fuel to earth orbit to feed the fueling pod farms. Awesome video. Although comparing delta-v with range is kind of a complete nonsense. Delta-v is simply maximum acceleration in space while range is how far it can go before running out of fuel, completely different thing. Delta-v simply put (of course there are more variables) is the amount of thrust the engine can give divided by the mass of the spacecraft while range is how much fuel can car hold divided by effectivity of the engine per km, nothing to do with speed or time whatsoever.
EDIT: Just googled it up and it actually is literally just thrust divided by mass, no other variables.

The actual ongoing risk was probably closer to 20% with hindsight, Apollo 13 was a save that defied any reasonable outcome given the failure. The Shuttle's risk was probably around 0.5% - 2% but NASA management put it at 0.01% or less a reflection of the political pandering and culture of dishonesty that has proven difficult to eliminate. Tourists die climbing Mount Everest at a rate of 6.5% yet nobody bats an eyelid. NASA should accept more risk and be honest about those risks and be more stoic in accepting the losses. You KNOW there are astronauts who will happily volunteer for the job at those risks.  It sounds great to talk about safer systems but when it costs literally tens of billions of dollars to mitigate the risk and save a handful of lives that is a horrendous waste of money and resources and it is killing our future in space. All because we don't have leadership that will grow a pair and explain the reality to the public. If you want to feel better about it erect a children's hospital dedicated to every dead astronaut and you'll still save $billions and many more lives.

They can't rebuild the Saturn V even if they wanted to, the know-how to do it has been lost. A lot of the stuff was never documented and the people that built it are either dead or probably don't remember why something was done the way it was. There are stories and anecdote that when Artemis was announced there were NASA engineers going to scrap yards and museums tracking down Apollo era hardware just to see how some of the stuff was done; to see how certain problems were solved by the Apollo engineers. I heard one story of how the current engineers came across a pipe that had an unexpected bend in it. There didn't seem to be an obvious reason for it to be bent that way but it was clearly shaped like that for a reason. The managed to track down the engineer who worked on that part of the rocket and he told them it was shaped like that so they could have enough room to get a tool in there to access something nearby. Things like that were never documented and only discovered through trial and error. Saturn V was built fast and 'good-enough', they were in a rush and decisions to do things a certain way were likely done ad hoc and on the fly just to get the rocket out the door on time. The amount of effort to reverse engineer the Saturn V would probably be similar what's been done developing SLS.

The development phase of any rocket system is expensive. The operational phase of SLS should be much cheaper than Shuttle. You design a vehicle very differently if you intend to use it once as opposed to using it over and over. You have to be absolutely sure it will work perfectly one time, vs. having to be sure it works perfectly multiple times it launches.

For shuttle, we had to basically reinsure the vehicle was in as close to pristine condition as possible each launch. The cost of that was incredible. And regardless of how much inspection, repair, upgrade and replacement that was done, the vehicle had a limited design life. Shuttle ran something like 10 years past its intended design life for the major structural elements.

So we could design another Shuttle like system, knowing the associated costs and problems with a reusable vehicle, or we could return to a more Apollo 'like' vehicle where the expensive parts of it were disposable.

That being said, we discovered that some portions of the Shuttle that were reusable were actually relatively cheap and safe. The SRBs. After Challenger, that may seem like an impossible statement, but with all of the redesigns and improvements made to the SRBs over the decades, they are very well understood technology. The cost compared to the thrust of SRBs is hard to beat with any other possible system. So we kept the SRBs and went from 4 segments to 5.

And the capsule. Relatively, the capsule is a small portion of the entire stacked vehicle. If there is a portion that can be inspected, repaired, and refurbished enough every flight in relatively inexpensive fashion, it's the capsule. And down the road if it turns out for unforeseen reasons that the capsule ISN'T cost effective to reuse, it won't be that big of a change to just start making new ones each launch.

The cost "savings" for NASA probably mean lowering the cost for a few billion dollars to still at least a billion. Then you have commercial rockets from the biggest contestors now (SpaceX and Blue Origin) which combined cost less than half a billion dollars. Even if you count in the number of people working on the projects the numbers going into the Artemis program are mind boggling... And don't even get me started on SpaceX' own lunar landing plans and China...

After my tour in the USMC, I had the good fortune of getting a job with IBM, who had won the NASA1400 contract. There were just a handful of us that developed, coded, and and executed the software that performed the final acceptance testing for the Saturn V IU, the instrument unit that was the brain of the launch system. The tests included PD&C, power distribution and control, EDS, emergency detection system, and General Networks, the program to validate all IU interface wiring, Sim Plug, which ran the simulation of disconnecting the IU from ground power while connecting to onboard battery power, and Sim Flight, the program that simulated the entire function of the IU up to stage separation of the S IVB stage. We used ATOLL, automatic test to launch language and typed our own 8080 punch cards, assembled the Atoll format programs into machine language using the IBM System 360, and ran the programs on a RCA 110. The IU's computer system consisted of a LVDA and LVDC, launch vehicle digital adaptor and launch vehicle digital computer, both about the size of a very large suitcase. The ST24 (stable table) which provided inertial guidance information was about the size of a 55 gal drum. All this took place in a few years, from 1965 to 1970 and was amazing for a former Upstate New York farm kid who had the good fortune of being part of history. Yet today I have a phone that would probably be able to do everything all this amazing hardware that cost less than $1000.

Finally watching this. The one thing that starts to set in is that engineering time isn't cheap. I started looking into hiring engineering time to design an aircraft and it turns out that it would be about $250k for all of the facilities and tooling, and about 2.5 million for 4 full time engineers to do the entire program over 3 years once you account for things like benefits and taxes. And engineers aren't getting bolder or any less risk averse, so unlike back in the day when a few horn rimmed glasses and a sharp pencil and a sharper vest would sign off on some murder-devices in the shape of an aerospace vehicle, today we need about 40 people to play hot potato with who's responsible for the paperwork for a year or so before everyone forgets what we're even building and agrees to sign the paperwork. At least, that's what I've seen in projects I've worked on.

Engineering time in the modern age has ballooned despite all the better technology. Engineering pay has ballooned because, well, obviously.

Certainly this doesn't even start to factor in allllll of the cruft and pork and milking and other things. That stuff is obviously a factor but always has been to some degree. Now we have companies that have decades of experience doing it, and there isn't some major patriotic imperative to push people to step outside that.

This doesn't mean that we don't have great engineers, or teams willing to push boundaries. It doesn't mean NASA isn't still impressive. It's all excellent. But the costs just become numbers, and everyone has to cover their lines and pad for uncertainty, from the engineer with a new house to the CEO debating whether to take on this job or push a different program, needing to make sure it pays off. No matter the reason, it all starts to add up FAST.

An important point on making cost comparisons over such a long time period. Really you should be comparing these costs as a proportion of national GDP (the Apollo programme was significant). That gives you a much better sense of how much of the country's resources were being devoted to these programmes. That's especially important if you want to know how sustainable these programmes are as you need to understand their opportunity cost - what proportion of their budgets are politicians having to forgo spending on other things (like education or tax cuts) in order to make the projects work. When you take that into account Artemis looks way more sustainable than Apollo.

The main decision that allowed the Apollo13 crew to survive was made by Grumman. not NASA. Tom Kelly chief engineer had to decide how big to make the LM  O2 tank when NASA rejected the LM Lifeboat option. He decided to leave the tank the same size as the Lifeboat option tank, figuring NASA might want longer moon missions and it would be harder to enlarge the tank size  If he allocated the space to other equipment. If had shrunk the tank to new required size the Astronauts would have suffocated before returning to Earth. Also a lot of the work to figure out how to save the mission was done by North American and Grumman Engineers, which the movie Apollo 13 completely glosses over. The Astronauts actually went around the country to shake the hands of everybody who worked on the LM.

Somehow I find it hard to believe that it will cost less to reinvent the wheel with SLS and Artemis, rather than simply picking up where we left off in 1973 with Saturn and Apollo.

Remember, we were told once before how much cheaper it would be to develop and fly a reusable Shuttle instead of Saturn/Apollo because the Shuttle would be "reusable".
It wasn't cheaper at all.
Wikipedia: "When all design and maintenance costs are taken into account, the final cost of the Space Shuttle program, averaged over all missions and adjusted for inflation, was estimated to come out to $1.5 billion per launch, or $60,000/kg (approximately $27,000 per pound) to LEO. This should be contrasted with the originally envisioned costs of $118 per pound of payload in 1972 dollars (approximately $635 per pound adjusting for inflation to 2011)."  That's over 40 times more expensive than promised and 4 times more expensive than it would have cost using Saturn 1B's.

It cost 209 billion (2011 dollars) and 14 lives to lauch 135 Shuttles, (Space.com) but the Saturn 1B could have orbited those same payloads for a fraction of the cost, without risking a single life. 135 Saturn 1b's at $336 million each (Wikipedia) = 46 billion (2019 dollars) That's a savings of over $ 163 billion, or 77%, compared to the shuttle. Those savings would have been enough to fund over 100 Saturn V rockets at $ 1.23 billion each (Wikipedia) and still left us with $ 40 billion left over. That $40 billion could have paid for a space station (Skylab) and a manned base on the Moon - See the Apollo Applications Program.

Now, once again we are being told how much money we will save with this new and improved program because the spacecraft will be reusable and sustainable. Sure. That's like saying you're going to save money on gas if you buy a new car - the cost of the car will far outweigh any savings in gas. But let's see just how sustainable NASA's operations have been since Saturn/Apollo.

Space Shuttle $ 209 Billion (Space.com)
Constellation 230 Billion (Wikipedia)
Orion capsule 21 Billion (Wikipedia0
Artemis 35 Billion (Wikipedia)
Total $495 Billion

VS 100 Saturn V trips to the moon ($123 billion) and 135 Saturn 1b launches to low earth orbit ($ 46 Billion). $169. Billion total, or a little over a third of what NASA shelled out going the "susttainable/reusable" route. Look at what the Russians have done with Soyuz. It's just gotten better, more reliable, and less expensive over time, probably because they couldn't afford to spend money on promises of something better when they already had something that worked.

There's an issue that needs to be considered, but is monumentally difficult for even seasoned accountants to grasp: sunk costs.

Essentially, a "sunk cost" is one you are not getting back. Regardless of where this is in development RIGHT NOW, all costs that have been spent would not be recovered by cancelling the project and substituting it with any alternatives. Those costs NASA has spent are gonzo. Ignore them. They're no longer important in the slightest. Don't amortize them, write them off.

The real issue now is to determine what the costs to complete will be compared to any alternative, like say an all-private, all-singing, all-dancing version, which could very well be starting from a near-blank CAD file. I bet it'll be a lot cheaper to complete the Artemis project as currently envisaged than to try to change the project at the last minute.

Tim as always fantastic video. One thing I will say though, is while I generally agree with your rant, actually the costs in restarting production of the RS25's is actually kind of standard regardless of what industry you are talking about. My expertise is defence where this kind of thing happens all the time and while generally governments are ripped off royally by contractors as they have no fiscal sense, restarting production of an old system/component is actually quite expensive. The tooling all has to be redone and to standards that generally are no longer extant, plus the supply chain has to source parts that are no longer made meaning they have to pay over the odds to sub contractors to even consider restarting a production line because quite simply restarting the logistics to build a system that is no longer extant is actually extremely non profitable, therefore everyone involved has to raise their costs massively. It actually makes you wonder why go with the RS25's? it only looks like a good idea until you get into the nuts and bolts of it.

That weird elliptical orbit around the moon takes 8 days. So at the end of 8 days, when the ship is near the moon where it can do a return burn the orbit is now way out of alignment with the direction needed to get home. Also, any lander needing to get back to the halo orbit station needs to wait for it to come back to a good rendezvous point. Others that are thought of as seasoned growth industries have actually stopped growing in every case, the reason growth is threatened slowed or stopped is not because the market is saturated, it is because there has been a failure of management. 22:10 - That's the one thing that annoys me about the Netflix series "Away" - (I'm not completely through it yet, though; there may be more.) They're "halfway to Mars" and yet the transmission delay is less than a second, and suddenly they go from being able to do full-quality, near-zero-delay video chat to "we're down to text messages".

THAT'S NOT HOW SIGNAL DEGRADATION OVER DISTANCE WORKS! You wouldn't go from "slightly glitchy no-delay video" to "emails once a day" in a matter of seconds of distance. Not to mention, of course, that video works just fine over distance. Just with longer transmission delays/latency, and maybe lower bandwidth requiring lower-quality video. But I have to imagine that if we were launching a crewed mission to Mars, we'd dedicate enough satellite bandwidth to be able to have video feeds the whole time, even if delayed.

I can fully understand not wanting to build in 3-minute delays for the sake of storytelling, but at least show the increased delays happening, then make it obvious narratively that you're cutting out the delays. You can't have one person mid-sentence interrupt the other person, and have the other person pause to let them talk when you're at a distance that should have at LEAST a 3-minute delay.

Or have the "we can't do live chats any more" be when it's a 5-second delay or something, and show how infuriating the 5-second delay is. (The scene with "last video chat" does have some people-with-interpersonal-communication-problems, the actual-real-physics multi-second delay would make that worse, and be a great narrative device!)

The video was an extremely well-done analysis. I agree with virtually everything stated for the reasons articulated. I would however, like to put some of these numbers in perspective. When discussing government programs, you can get "billions" insensitive. It is hard to understand how much the totals actually mean. For example, the USS Gerald R. Ford (CVN 78), a 100,000-ton state of the art nuclear aircraft carrier, is estimated to cost at least $13 billion; $5 billion for research and development plus $8 billion to build. $31 billion for Artemis 1?!!!! That is the cost to construct four Ford class aircraft carriers. Lots of people from Boeing and NASA should not only be fired but be in jail for accepting those incredible costs. As said, the SLS is nothing much more than a collection of used and old parts. For it to cost that must deserves more than a rant. The Orion is perhaps not totally comparable to Apollo, but it is loosely akin to the Crewed Dragon. The Dragon 2 is not designed for the precise mission as is Orion, but It could be and could have been. The Dragon 2 funded development costs were around $2.6 billion. Perhaps to make a Dragon 2 version that could do what Orion is supposed to do would cost twice as much or $5.2 billion to be unkind to SpaceX. However, $13.6 billion for a capsule is so utterly outrageous that again people from NASA and Lockheed should be fired and jailed. The lack of being good stewards of the taxpayer’s money makes one's blood boil. Artemis is not sustainable. A permanent manned settlement on the moon is not possible with Artemis. We might as well give the Moon to the Chinese. The only hope NASA and the United States has is Starship / Super Heavy. Let us all pray for Elon's continued good health.

Apollo and Artemis are very different programs also for a reason which doesn't come up here: Artemis is international, which people in the USA (and NASA, when it's convenient) tend to forget. ESA builds the Orion service module. Noticed Thales Alenia participating in one of the lunar landers? European. Long range lunar manned rover for Artemis will be built in Japan. Not to speak of Gateway, with Canadian, European, Japanese and Russian participation. This both brings down costs for NASA and makes abandoning the Artemis project harder for political reasons. Refusing to acknowledge the international aspect also makes it thus harder to see why in the long run Artemis is more likely than not in reaching the goal of a permanent human presence on the Moon.

The biggest problem has been the use of that rare heavy element, governmentium:

Published in
The Irish Times

Scientists discover heaviest known element - governmentium

MAGPIE:
SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH has led to the discovery of the heaviest element yet known


The new element, governmentium (Gv), has one neutron, 25 assistant neutrons, 88 deputy neutrons, and 198 assistant deputy neutrons, giving it an atomic mass of 312.

These 312 particles are held together by forces called morons, which are surrounded by vast quantities of lepton-like particles called peons. Since governmentium has no electrons, it is inert; however, according to the team of research scientists in Budapest, it can be detected because it impedes every reaction with which it comes into contact.

Governmentium has a normal half-life of two to six years. It does not decay, but instead undergoes a reorganisation in which a portion of the assistant neutrons and deputy neutrons exchange places.

In fact, governmentium’s mass will actually increase over time, since each reorganisation will cause more morons to become neutrons, forming isodopes. This characteristic of moron promotion leads some scientists to believe that governmentium is formed whenever morons reach a critical concentration. This hypothetical quantity is referred to as critical morass.

When catalysed with money, governmentium becomes administratium, an element that radiates just as much energy as governmentium since it has half as many peons but twice as many morons.

Yes, Artemis is expensive for what we're getting, but it pales in comparison to cost overruns routinely experienced in our US military programs (F-35 anyone?).  And Artemis is mostly about exploration and moving the human species outward into the solar system, and as inefficiently and as expensively as it will be, I find that more worth the cost than military expenditures beyond self-defense.  The military (most of it) is really about maintaining world economic hegemony (i.e., greed).  Both Artemis and military spending are "good" for economies, but Artemis helps humanity, whereas overspending on military programs, not so much.  My hope is that Artemis is the last large program driven by the US government, and that subsequent programs are funded by private sector capital.  With the wealth creation enabled by automation (now and forthcoming), the money will be there, and as long as we keep relatively free, the entrepreneurs will be there also.  Anyway, that's my view as a 24-year Air Force vet.

This is fundamental and all Mechanical Engineers know it:
Aluminum Alloys go to ZERO strength over time. After enough stress cycles, Aluminum cracks continue to grow, and it turns into a powder, and it disintegrates! Google Aloha Airlines Flight 243! #1 Development costs always cost more than in-production costs, because you have to create and validate the infrastructure. #2 When you change the specifications for existing designs, you still have to redesign and revalidate, especially for risk-of-life spaceflight. #3 Spaceflight will never be cheap because there will never be economies of scale - it will be "cheap" in quotes, but not truly commodity cheap. So rant all you want, you can't get a latest-and-greatest iPhone at Wal-Mart prices - at least until it been around for quite a while. And oh yeah - something called inflation. And keep in mind, if there's deflation, then your space program is really gonna be up the creek.

People try to justify Artemis constantly however I think its just a product of the sunk cost fallacy. The Artemis program costs so much that if you just launched all the hardware in segments on falcon heavies (which are definitely not designed to go to the moon) you would still save a staggering sum. Further, because Artemis relies on premade hardware they haven't even constructed much of the actual production lines meaning there will not be frequent flights of Artemis in the near future and 'projects' like the lunar gateway are going to take decades if they are ever actually built. The space shuttle program ended in 2011 and it has taken over a decade to even seemly be close to the first launch of a rocket which was selected because it was supposedly 'easy' to build and 'cheap'.  The question is if the Artemis program was cancelled today and the ~80 billion yet to be spent was instead directed towards commercial companies would they be able to launch more mass to the moon? I think undeniably the answer is a resounding yes.

A few words on Orions Service Module: I think it makes sense for it to be so small, since Orion isn't just build for the moon, but it is also supposed to be used for Mars. When you build a capsule solely for the Moon, like Apollo CSM, the approach of having the command module do all the pushing around and returning to earth makes sense, since things are generally lighter that 30 tons and Delta-V requirements are only 2x800 m/s=1600m/s. However, when you look at a Mars Mission, different components can easily weigh more than 50 tons and Delty-V requirements for capture and return are much bigger. Giving Orion a Service Module big enough to accomplish all those goals would be hugely inefficient and would turn Orion more into a crewed space tug than simply a manned capsule. All the pushing-around would be done by high-energy transfer stages like the blie Origin lander one. I feel like Artemis' weird approach to lunar landing is not only dictated by the need to communicate 24/7, but also by Orion's Mars-worthy construction.

Hi Tim. Just a comment about your repulsion of Cost/Plus contracts...apart from the fact that the United States Space Program is indirectly a tool used by the political establishment to maintain jobs in various regions of the country as are Military spendings, the difference between a cost/plus contract and a fixed cost contract is about who is taking the risk.  On risky projects where there is a lot of innovation and unknowns, the "Client" must evaluate if he wants to transfer the risk to the supplier and pay a significant amount of money for it with a fixed cost contract or take itself the means to control the risk and have a cost-plus project where there is no amount allocated for the risk by the supplier.  On top of that, we can add the fact that in the vast majority of cases, when the risk was incorrectly evaluated by the supplier, the supplier fails and goes bankrupt.  When this happen and there is no other supplier that can fulfill the place left by the bankrupt supplier (which is usually the case with space programs), the project is Kaput...Then the client, in this case the american government, supports the supplier by injecting even more money for it to fulfill the contract...So, in the end, what is the difference?  I think the solution is competition where the supply of solutions is not at the mercy of only one supplier whether it is a fixed cost or a cost/plus.  When the solution is well established and reliable, then a fixed cost contract is the way to go.

Great video. I appreciate the analysis - which am sure was especially tough when you already have a strong feeling about a conclusion that frustrates you.
My dad went to work for NASA JSC in 1969 to support the Lunar Landings and he continued through to the Shuttle.
So, I grew up in that environment and though I decided to be an Engineer, I had no interest in working for NASA or a NASA contractor after seeing it from the inside.
Yes, I lot of amazing things were developed as a result of these programs; but, I really could not stomach the rules you had to play by.
Note: Don't think this is because I can't handle high quality, disciplined development - I have worked most of my life developing and manufacturing pacemakers and defibrillators.
I still remember how excited I was as teenager and young about the Space Shuttle - a reusable system that could make going to space like a plane ride. My dad knew that and even got me photos of the launch and landing of the first shuttle signed by the first two crews. Then I recall later when I learned the truth about the "re-usability" of the Shuttle - I felt SO DECEIVED. Couple that with the Challenger and Columbia disasters, I was pretty shaken and pretty pissed too.
SLS in some ways seems like more of the same. I know that much of that has happened is because of the political environment that NASA has to operate under and that many NASA employees are truly exceptional and much of the decisions that I can't stomach occur at a much higher level - still they were ones I just couldn't liver under - I know the ends are good; but, the means was just not something I could live with.
Hearing what happened at Boeing for Starliner during OFT was another shocker - I would really love to see their Risk Analysis and Test Verification reports. Those errors could have easily been missed during CFT and have been result in a loss of life and were easily preventable by taking life dependent development seriously. I know people make mistakes - I know I do - that is why we have processes to review, analyse, and verify. In the cases of the OFT issues, it seems like a culture change caused them to move away from those principles.

As always, youl've done an excellent job with this video and the associated explanatory material on your website. With regard to your question (was this the right way to go, or should NASA opted for a revamped program using fundamental Apollo-era hardware, like the F1 rocket, the CM/SM and LEM, the S4B and so on).

In a nutshell, ✖︎ ("no"). The question, of course, is also a bit non sequitur, as NASA has gone ahead with Orion / Artemis / SLS. But even so, the answer is still ✖︎ ("no"). The technical innovations and safety advances alone appear to suggest that the decision to come up with a new system have been worth it.

The bigger question, of course, is whether Boeing and the other "Cost Plus" contractors that dominated the space program in the past will survive the onslaught of more commercially viable programs run by SpaceX, Blue Origin and (eventually) others?

Then, of course, are the very real concerns about the low DeltaV that's been designed into the new service module...

On the Rant; I am always first in line to defend NASA's budget. They get a tiny fraction of the US' annual budget, especially when compared to the DOD, the comparison that's always made, fairly or not. And yes, there are plenty of naysayers with arguments like 'we have enough problems here on earth, why should we spend money on space' which are defensive, and missing the point, and have absolutely no interest in looking forward. Artemis as is will never happen because the SLS will only fly once if ever.

NASA's "Artemis" and "SLS" program, currently in progress, is one of, if not THE biggest wastes of time and money in not just the history of spaceflight, but of pretty much ALL flight in-general.

I remember hearing about seven or eight years ago (perhaps a bit longer) that NASA was building something called "The Constellation Program", and they were just a year or two from launching what would be the most massive space-rocket in the history of spaceflight.

That we were just a matter of two to three years away from launching men and women to the moon for much longer stays than Apollo, and would even be manufacturing their own fuel on the moon for the trip back, after a short stop and stay at the ISS on the way back to the Earth for some rest after working on the moon.

And it also seems there was more to the story, like launching first to the ISS to transfer tools, food, and so-on to a shuttle-type craft already parked at the ISS, to ferry astronauts to a waiting Lunar Gateway orbiting the moon, where a landing craft would already have been launched/docked, waiting for the astronauts to arrive, and descend to the surface.

Then the astronauts would gather samples, work, and somehow constitute rocket-fuel from frozen water found in the craters at/near the Lunar South Pole.

Then they would get back in the landing craft, refuel it not only to launch back up to the gateway, but also re-fueled for the next crew's descent. Then they would transfer the samples and whatever over to the shuttle craft, and make their way back to the ISS for a short period of rest before transferring the samples, tools, and/or etc. back over to the launch vehicle (which is now called the "Earth-return vehicle").

After a few days/weeks rest and possibly some physical tests, they say their goodbyes to the ISS Crew, then ingress the Earth-return vehicle, and descend back to the surface of the Earth, either on land or in the ocean.

But here we are about seven or eight years later (or perhaps even longer). The name of the vehicle has been changed to "Artemis" (the twin-sister of Apollo - which is like, super-cool)!

But I'm not seeing a completed "Artemis" launch-vehicle (there's bits and pieces strewn about about the confines of the VAB, in Mississippi, even in Utah, and probably other locations, but no completed genuine article mounted on a crawler-transporter, ready to go make the Saturn V look like a kindergarten science project...

And I can't help but wonder "Why?" - I mean there's the usual words and phrases we became familiar with from the days of Mercury and Gemini, Apollo, Skylab, and the Space Shuttles; such as over-budget, miscalculated final costs, parts made by one company don't match up to the parts made by another (Apollo 13 air-filters come to mind...), inadequate testing, magnificent desolation, "The Eagle has Landed", and "One Small Step for Man". Then we all held our breath and each other's hands until Jim Lovell, after the Command Module of Apollo had taken too long to emerge from radio silence, finally uttered the words, "Houston, 13"; and immediately the entire world drew a breath of relief, suddenly realizing that we were going to get our astronauts back home, alive, uninjured, and safe!

But now we have to look at SpaceX, that got off to a small bit of a rocky start, but is now, along with the Soyuz, the most dependable human-rated spaceship on the planet. And along with the fact that SpaceX and the Soyuz in-general, along with ULA, Northrup-Grumman, Arianespace, ILS, Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, ISC Kosmotras Rocket Lab, Spaceflight Industries, and Eurockot Launch Services are all leading the way in satellite and space exploration services; it's a shame there isn't one company listed by the name of NASA currently on the list.

Additionally, with names like "Jeff Bezos" and his "New Glenn" rocket, along with Richard Branson's "Virgin Galactic", which intends upon becoming the first private company to take customers to space, one begins to wonder if there's even a spot, or a need for what seems to be a nearly defunct NASA.

I hope I'm wrong, I seriously hope I'm wrong... Although right now I have to admit my heart belongs to SpaceX, which is pretty much the most exciting thing going on in the realm of space exploration (who else can land a spent booster-rocket on a platform roughly 200 miles from the launch point, which is like shooting dead-center a mosquito with a needle at a distance of several hundred feet?).

Along with the goings on at Boca Chica, SpaceX is definitely presently carrying the torch, they have been for quite some time now (let's not forget about the Falcon Heavy), and if NASA doesn't do a "Headline Maker" pretty soon, I'm very much afraid that Kennedy Space Center may become the headquarters of SpaceX, and NASA may simply become an encyclopedia article.

IMO personally, the Artemis program and the SLS needed to be here at least 10 years ago. That being said, when the program began, it was still the only serious option on the table for actually getting us back to the moon that has sadly had to face far more politics than it should have. Its easy to look at SLS with hindsight and go "Yeah, how did NASA not expect private companies to do the impossible and start landing rockets back from space and bring the cost down an order of magnitude?!" When in reality when SLS entered production, nobody had anything comparable in performance, or even really cost, Falcon 9 hadn't even successfully landed yet.

As it is now, it's in the unenviable position of likely being completely obsolete by the time it actually flies, but it was still the best option at the time, and is still the best option until those other options are actually flying. Hopefully once something like Starship, or New Glenn is flying, NASA kills off the SLS program in favor of those, since they're vastly more cost-effective and far less wasteful in the long run. I really hope Bridenstein and future NASA administrators realize that another NASA developed vehicle like the Saturn-V, Space Shuttle or SLS isn't viable anymore and that SLS is the last time they do this. Politics plays far too big of a role in making these projects as expensive as they are. Seeing more commercial programs, where NASA gives them a set of basic guidelines and requirements, and everyone is free to submit whatever design meets those and picking multiple for redundancy is the best option for the long term.

I think it’s important to note that Orion’s low delta v numbers were because originally it was too travel to the moon with the LSAM / Altair. Altair would perform the lunar breaking burn. When Altair and constellation were cancelled Orion kept these metrics assuming if lunar missions were to be developed again they would have a lunar lander to perform the burn or a Lagrange station (gateway)

redoing the Apollo program would have been the step backwards. Putting a station into permanent (or as permanent as it gets) orbit around the moon makes a lot of sense. Just like having a permanent station for refueling in LEO makes sense. It let's you use cheaper rockets to stage material for the big trip. It's not as exciting, but in the long run, it makes a lot of sense.

For example, if you could use, say falcon heavies or delta heavies to put segments of the actual TLI, and HLS in orbit, and send the command module up last, you could actually take a reasonable tonnage of material to the moon to build a base. Again, not sexy, but it would (IMHO) be the best bet.
Give all the funding to SpaceX, they'll know what to do with it.

Honestly looking at those cost over-runs for the SLS, I do think the re-birth and re-vamping of the Saturn V (with perhaps even including the original idea of making at least the 1st stage recoverable) would have been a better course.  The fact SLS needs to use SRBs opposed to just having 5 massive engines for the first stage combined with the fact the SLS is LESS capable to me is just inexcusable.  But I am familiar with this being in the Aerospace industry where in the light general aviation field Cessna spent MORE for a far less capable aircraft (the Cessna 162 sky catcher), than they did for the venerable Cessna 150/152.  (actually the 152 is just a revamp and re-engining of the venerable Cessna 150, which had THE SAME ENGINE, Continental O-200, that decades later would power the Cessna 162).  It just seems like those at the helm of these big companies lack the common sense of seeing how when something costs more, but is less capable than an already tried and trusted design....there is something amiss.   The Orion is just baffling as well.  I totally get going for solar power opposed to power cells, but why a service module that again is less capable than the Apollo's SM?  Again, common sense would suggest the SM for a CM that is bigger and with more crew capacity would require either an SM of the same power and DV, or MORE, not less.  The lunar landers I think are the only aspect of this program that make any sense.  I LIKE the Starship, but I also like the lander that seems to only jettison two tanks....but if things were done different perhaps there would be no need to even do that.  Re-usable landers in this day and age are a must, so the fact all three are either fully or partially re-usable is a good thing to see.  But...the SLS.  Does the term "boondoggle" come to mind? 10:35 says the system is 2/3 reusable. Does anyone have concrete information indicating that the Transfer Element (TE) will be reused? I’ve closely parsed the initial publicity text, and it only mentioned the TE being used to get the other elements to low lunar orbit. It said nothing about any rendezvous to return the ascent stage to NRHO where Orion will be waiting. One might assume the TE would be involved in the latter, but is that more than an assumption? (In the Dynetics design drop tanks are used in one direction only, and the lander gets itself back to NRHO. It’s at least theoretically possible that the National Team have made a similar design choice. Though, it’s not clear why such a choice would make sense for the TE, aside from eliminating the need for a rendezvous, and avoiding the need for another docking interface.) / In the case of the Blue Origin landing stage, there are indications that BO is thinking about reuse. Apollo exceeded it's 5% failure estimate if your measure of success is ONLY the "...and return them alive" part
If you include the "send a man to the moon..." part, then 1 of 7 landing attempts failed, which is a 16% failure rate.
If you're morbidly inclined, of 32 Apollo astronauts, 3 died on the program, a 9% failure rate. (0 of the 24 that flew lunar missions died)

No! Its the opposite, its a highly uneliptial suborbital trijectory.
Think about it, elipticity is exentricity and high relative difference between apogee and peragee. A normal suborbital trijectory has its peragee deep inside the earth, making the difference between apogee and peragee much greater.
This trijectory has a very low relative difference between apogee and peragee (nearly negligible hundreds of kilometers) and thus it has low exentricity, making it much less eliptical.
